name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element, but allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place. Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d, and the concept of a cyclic shift can be explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, resulting in a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of the original elements of the segment, so in the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5]. Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments, noting that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts, and any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5] 

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l...r]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def solve():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append("0")
            continue
        
        # Strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(n-1, i, -1):
                if a[j] < a[j-1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to swap a[j] and a[j-1]
                    l = j - 1
                    r = j
                    d = 1
                    cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                    actions.append(f"{l+1} {r+1} {d}")
        
        # Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]
        
        results.append(str(len(actions)))
        results.extend(actions)
    
    # Print all results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    solve()

main()
completions:
def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l...r]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, a):
    actions = []
    sorted_a = sorted(a)
    
    if a == sorted_a:
        return 0, actions
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n-1, i, -1):
            if a[j] < a[j-1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[j] to the correct position
                l = j - 1
                r = j
                d = 1
                cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                actions.append((l+1, r+1, d))
    
    return len(actions), actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        k, actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, a)
        results.append(f"{k}")
        for action in actions:
            results.append(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        # We will use a simple strategy to sort the array
        # by moving the largest unsorted element to its correct position
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = r - l
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index+1:index+1+n]))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += n + 1
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, array = test_cases[i]
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        # This is not optimized but ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n
        for j in range(n):
            if array[j] != sorted_array[j]:
                # Find the position of the correct element in the unsorted array
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[j], j)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > j:
                    d = correct_pos - j
                    actions.append((j + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[j:correct_pos + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[j:correct_pos + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for case in test_cases:
        n, array = case
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        # Implement a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it will work within the constraints
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the front
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r + 1, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:r + 1]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:r + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)

                if correct_pos > i:
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = array[i + d:correct_pos + 1] + array[i:i + d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, a = test_cases[i]
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for j in range(n):
            if a[j] != sorted_a[j]:
                # Find the correct position of a[j] in the sorted array
                correct_pos = j
                for k in range(j, n):
                    if sorted_a[k] == a[j]:
                        correct_pos = k
                        break
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[j] to its correct position
                if correct_pos > j:
                    l = j + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = correct_pos - j
                    a[j:r] = a[j+d:r] + a[j:j+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):

            continue
        
        # Sort the array using cyclic shifts
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        for j in range(n):
            if array[j] != sorted_array[j]:
                # Find the segment that needs to be shifted
                l = j + 1
                r = array.index(sorted_array[j], j) + 1
                d = r - l
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l...r]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def solve():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append("0")
            continue
        
        # Strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(n-1, i, -1):
                if a[j] < a[j-1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to swap a[j] and a[j-1]
                    l = j - 1
                    r = j
                    d = 1
                    cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                    actions.append(f"{l+1} {r+1} {d}")
        
        # Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]
        
        results.append(str(len(actions)))
        results.extend(actions)
    
    # Print all results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    solve()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l...r]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, a):
    actions = []
    sorted_a = sorted(a)
    
    if a == sorted_a:
        return 0, actions
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n-1, i, -1):
            if a[j] < a[j-1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[j] to the correct position
                l = j - 1
                r = j
                d = 1
                cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                actions.append((l+1, r+1, d))
    
    return len(actions), actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        k, actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, a)
        results.append(f"{k}")
        for action in actions:
            results.append(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        # We will use a simple strategy to sort the array
        # by moving the largest unsorted element to its correct position
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = r - l
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index+1:index+1+n]))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += n + 1
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":

        for j in range(n):
            if array[j] != sorted_array[j]:
                # Find the position of the correct element in the unsorted array
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[j], j)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for case in test_cases:
        n, array = case
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        # Implement a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it will work within the constraints
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the front
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r + 1, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:r + 1]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:r + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read

    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):

        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n

    results = []

        for j in range(n):

                # Find the correct position of a[j] in the sorted array
                correct_pos = j
                for k in range(j, n):
                    if sorted_a[k] == a[j]:

                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[j] to its correct position
                if correct_pos > j:

                    r = correct_pos + 1

                    a[j:r] = a[j+d:r] + a[j:j+d]

Round_0.code:
def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l...r]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def solve():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append("0")
            continue
        
        # Strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(n-1, i, -1):
                if a[j] < a[j-1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to swap a[j] and a[j-1]
                    l = j - 1
                    r = j
                    d = 1
                    cyclic_shift(a, l, r, d)
                    actions.append(f"{l+1} {r+1} {d}")
        
        # Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n
        if len(actions) > n:
            actions = actions[:n]
        
        results.append(str(len(actions)))
        results.extend(actions)
    
    # Print all results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    solve()

prompt:
The new generation external memory includes an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n]. This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element, but allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place. Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d, and the concept of a cyclic shift can be explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, resulting in a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of the original elements of the segment, so in the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5]. Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments, noting that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts, and any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
